0.00.text:
Translator: Linndy V
Reviewer: Kelwalin Dhanasarnsombut

27.58.text: By all accounts, I was a very weird kid.

32.62.text:
I was painfully shy,
and if anyone talked to me,

35.22.text:
I would just stare at my shoes,
which I got to know pretty well.

40.17.text: I was also daydreaming all the time,

43.20.text:
and being accused
of being in my own world.

47.18.text:
At my first year in school,
I was flagged for "special attention,"

53.58.text:
after an exercise
where we had a list of words,

56.90.text:
and we had to organize them
into two categories;

66.34.text:
but I was kept back because
I put the word "sandwich" into "people."

72.62.text:
"Sandwich" to me, was a magical woman
who lived on the beach.

82.50.text: It was fairly obvious, I thought.

86.27.text: I also had an unsual childhood.

88.47.text: You see, my dad was a nuclear physicist.

92.20.text:
He spent a lot of time
examining subatomic particles.

98.01.text:
And these are the building blocks
of everything,

101.38.text: the very fabric of the universe.

103.98.text:
And it was challenging
trying to communicate this

106.66.text: to my 8-year-old friends at the time.

110.48.text:
Because of his research,
I traveled the world a lot,

113.20.text: and I kept moving school and country

116.79.text: which made me disconnected from people.

120.79.text:
As hard as I tried, I just 
couldn't understand why it was important

125.58.text: what a local sports team did with a ball.

130.70.text:
But where I did feel connected
is when we lived in Geneva.

135.84.text:
That was a wonderful childhood
formative experience for me.

141.07.text: When I visited him at work,

142.52.text:
I got to play with these
amazing things called "computers."

146.51.text: Me and computers, we knew each other.

149.70.text:
But what was the most inspiring thing
was witnessing these teams of scientists

158.63.text: They would get protons and neutrons,

162.37.text:
in an underground accelerator
at almost the speed of light,

167.54.text:
and they would explode
into the new hitherto unseen particles.

175.51.text:
I was struck not only
by the intelligence of these scientists

180.44.text:
working together, collaborating
to further the limit of human knowledge,

186.23.text:
but actually this aesthetic beauty
of those images like the one you see now.

192.21.text:
It was as if the they were creating
science and art at the same time.

198.24.text:
And another way that I felt connected
with others was through music.

202.83.text:
My dad played us everything
from Bartók to the Muppets,

207.87.text:
but when my uncle gave me
a cassette tape,

210.93.text:
which I don't know if you know,
it's a kind of retro MP3.

215.66.text:
It was the Beatles,
and on one side it had "Sgt. Pepper's,",

219.55.text:
and the other side,
it had "Magical Mystery Tour."

222.71.text:
And when I heard it, my tiny brain
exploded, like a million particles.

228.30.text:
There was a particular song,
"Blue Jay Way,"

230.95.text:
which, not only the lyrics,
but the melody and the harmony,

234.11.text:
seemed to exactly reflect my feeling
of disconnection with people.

240.66.text:
And I couldn't understand how
these musicians knew how to organize sound

246.96.text: so that I felt this way.

250.81.text: Now to me, as a naive boy,

253.71.text:
science and music
were actually the same thing.

257.50.text:
They were both about wonder
took extraordinary skills and dedication.

263.71.text:
And they were both about discovery,
about the universe,

267.96.text: and about ourselves, our inner worlds.

273.76.text:
However, the educational system
of the time told me,

277.72.text:
in no uncertain terms,
that they were, in fact, separate.

280.74.text:
They were taught at different times,
different parts of the school.

284.72.text: And one was serious, and one was play.

288.55.text:
It didn't make any sense to me,
and ultimately, I had to choose.

291.58.text:
And I chose the sciences.
I went and got a degree in Economics.

297.57.text: But by the end of my third year,

300.18.text:
my dad lost a short and brutal battle
to cancer, aged 51.

307.02.text:
And I realized life was short,
so I switched,

310.62.text: and I turned to my passion of music,

312.42.text:
and went to study
at Berkley College of Music

314.53.text:
where I endeavored to understand
the mechanics of music.

318.85.text:
And I learned that in fact,
these two worlds were more connected

325.43.text:
When we talk about scales and chords
and intervals and the cycle of fifths,

329.30.text:
what we were doing is making 
geometric shapes, mathematical models

338.60.text:
This, for example, is my analysis
of a John Coltrane solo.

343.57.text:
Each of these bubbles are a phrase
that he played, that he improvised,

347.94.text:
and they've been placed
in a three-dimensional space,

350.75.text:
of all the possible choices
he could have made.

353.57.text: And this is the improvisation he took.

355.51.text:
What I like about about this
is it reminds me

357.65.text:
of the bubbles chamber images
I saw all those years before.

362.63.text:
So, we can reveal patterns from music,
but I was fascinated to discover

367.81.text:
that we can actually
place patterns within it.

371.61.text:
The composer Bach was fortunate enough
to have a last name

376.82.text:
which spells out a four-note melody
in the German notation system: "B-A-C-H."

383.30.text:
He used it most famously
in "The Art of Fugue,"

385.71.text: which turned out to be his last piece.

387.63.text:
This piece is dictated from his deathbed,
in his blindness to his son,

392.96.text:
and you can see how it is incomplete
as the melodies trickle away.

398.47.text:
One of the last melodies he wrote
within that is his own name, "B-A-C-H,"

408.48.text:
So, we can put names into music. 
So, how about other things?

413.17.text: And in fact, this is an ancient idea.

416.78.text:
Pythagoras talked about
the music of the spheres,

419.41.text: a harmony created by the planets' orbits.

423.07.text:
And in the early 17th century,
Kepler even suggested scales for these,

428.31.text: based on the eccentricity of these orbits.

432.28.text:
There is a poet-philosopher called Rilke
from the early 20th century,

436.80.text: who wrote an essay in which he observed

440.56.text: that the human skull had this seam

443.86.text:
that keeps the parts together,
called the coronal suture.

447.74.text:
And he noted that it had
some similarities to a sound wave,

453.06.text:
or what he said,
"the groove of a phonograph."

456.35.text: And he posed a hypothetical question:

458.21.text:
What would happen if we tricked
a needle into playing that pattern?

463.32.text:
What sounds would come out,
and what feelings would be evoked?

468.19.text:
Now in 1919, this was a purely
hypothetical question.

473.13.text:
But in 2004, using my old friend
the computer, that's exactly what I did.

481.48.text:
What you're hearing are sounds
converted from a Victorian woman's skull,

485.51.text:
who would have lived
at the same time as Rillke.

488.99.text:
What I love about this is that never
in a million years,

493.55.text:
with a stack of blank paper
and a lot of coffee.

497.26.text:
It's as if it was music
that was in the universe

503.89.text:
Very shortly after I finished this piece, 
a tiny event would happen to me

509.14.text: that would have a huge impact on my life.

513.16.text: In the DNA of one of my white blood cells,

518.66.text: two parts of chromosome, nine and 22,

522.37.text:
happened to break off
and do a little dancing, switch places.

526.82.text:
And that created a new gene,
which had one instruction: replicate.

532.90.text: And what that meant for me is I acquired

536.19.text:
a rare, very fast-growing,
and very dangerous form of leukemia.

542.13.text:
On Friday, I was teaching
at the Royal Academy of Music,

544.99.text:
on Monday, I was in an ambulance,
being rushed to hospital

548.69.text: where I would live for several months,

551.05.text:
receiving a strict regime
of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

556.36.text:
I was put in isolation
because my immunity was shot.

559.84.text: So my poor wife, family, and friends

562.53.text:
could only visit me
wearing gowns and masks.

566.57.text:
So, stuck in that isolation ward, alone,
first of all, I invented a memory system,

573.22.text:
so I learned all the reigns
of the British monarchy.

578.80.text: And then I did a hundred artists.

582.35.text:
But then I noticed that everyday,
I was given my blood cell results

589.55.text:
and I started noticing
ins each of the population of blood cells,

593.62.text:
some really interesting,
actually musical patterns.

599.04.text:
So what I decided to do
is just do what I did before.

605.19.text:
I let the blood cells compose a piece
which I called "Bloodlines."

612.00.text:
So each day, I wrote
a second of this music .

615.53.text:
One second at a time,
just to pass the time.

619.37.text:
I say I wrote it, but actually,
my blood cells wrote it.

622.30.text:
I just received the royalties
on their behalf.

625.91.text:
So I'm going to play you
a little portion of it now.

635.33.text:
That "Whoosh" at the beginning
was my leukemia crisis,

637.99.text:
and now it's descending because
of the chemotherapy I've been receiving.

644.58.text:
Now thanks to the frontier
of medical knowledge,

649.76.text: and thanks to a bone marrow transplant

655.42.text:
which turned my blood type
from O+ to O-, from male to female,

661.63.text:
and incidentally makes me
resistant to malaria,

667.84.text:
which is quite nice, 
it has its benefits,

681.07.text: on the day I was diagnosed,

685.35.text: required me to produce a sample

688.79.text:
in case I survived,
a sample of a personal nature.

693.38.text: This was kept on ice for eight years.

696.52.text:
And now my wife and I have
a beautiful three-year-old daughter,

703.19.text:
called Chloe, which is a Greek word
for "little shoot of life".

708.13.text: When I look at her, I realize

713.41.text:
that her existence is even more
improbable than mine.

718.65.text:
I went on to do a PhD in composition,
and connected with people

722.53.text:
because I collaborated
with space scientists,

726.98.text:
getting the harmony
of distant planets, distant galaxies.

731.31.text:
I've worked with sleep scientists,
turning sleep patterns into music,

736.79.text:
mine are particularly funky
with a three-year-old in the house,

742.09.text:
I've worked with mathematicians,
I've worked with climate scientists.

745.55.text:
The melody goes up, by the way,
in case you're wondering.

751.61.text:
I've even worked with sociologists
and psychologists,

754.76.text:
because, in fact, there is a pattern
to even human behavior,

760.20.text:
even when we're acting intuitively,
we have our ways, we have our patterns.

764.69.text: I'm trying to think of an example.

767.18.text:
Like when you guys walked in today,
you had to pick your seat,

772.88.text:
and that was based on various things:
whether you have a good view,

776.11.text:
you didn't want to be too far away
from someone you knew to be rude,

780.38.text: or too close to a stranger to be weird.

784.66.text:
You might have shifted your position
because you might have redecided,

789.28.text:
and we could even write a piece
just of you guys coming in,

793.93.text:
and the music of your independent
thoughts, your own worlds.

800.22.text:
I say, "Could have,"
but that's what we did.

806.11.text:
When you walked in,
we, from the top, filmed you coming in.

810.62.text:
And then I went to a little room
and worked quite hard.

814.62.text: I told you I was weird.

817.64.text:
So, if you imagine this
as a strings on a harp,

821.06.text: from low to high, from left to right.

824.54.text:
So as each person sits down,
or shifts in their seat,

829.36.text: The height, by the way, is the volume.

832.29.text:
There's another element
which is as you're seated,

835.31.text:
you'll produce a string sound,
a nice, warm string sound,

842.56.text:
And one more thing, mobile phones,
anyone browsing on a mobile phones

847.39.text:
producing a light,
adds this extra resonance.

862.97.text:
Top right, he keeps moving,
he keeps playing different notes.

876.90.text:
Feel the warmth?
Feel the warmth of your seats.

887.20.text:
That's high siren,
that's the mobile phones.

893.52.text:
Shifts ahead a little bit
as it's filled up.

904.63.text:
Look at all those phones,
you naughty people.

928.59.text:
I'm not sure why you're clapping me,
it was your piece.

938.26.text:
I've rediscovered something
that I instinctively knew

942.50.text:
as a nine-year-old
gazing into bubble chambers,

948.55.text:
Music is more profound than love songs
and mere entertainment.

954.23.text:
And there is music
in everything around us.

961.41.text:
from the galaxies,
down to subatomic particles,

965.70.text:
and somewhere in the middle,
our little lives, loves, and pains.

973.66.text:
These are not disconnected,
but interwoven melodies

979.08.text:
in an infinite and beautiful
cosmic symphony.

994.73.text:
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
